<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16208>

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I can't reproduce this bug anymore, hopefully this is because it has been fixed
in the meantime. If you can still reproduce using current version of R, please
feel free to re-open and give additional details on how to reproduce.

I am not sure I fully understand the bug description - how should one type
"quit()" in the console when the window is minimized? And even while the
packages are being updated?

When running update.packages() (or install.packages()), Rgui will wait for the
result of the operation and not allow to type any additional commands. Closing
the Rgui windows via the X button will type "quit()" to the console and press
enter, which again cannot happen while an operation such as upgrading packages
is in progress.

I've been trying combinations I could think of, but didn't find a problem in
the current version of R. If say package installation is running, one can
interrupt that using the interrupt button, and then one can exit R (by typing
"quit()" or by the X button). One can also press the X button while the
operation is in progress, but the exit will only happen once the operation
finished. So e.g. one can press the X button and then the interrupt button,
which will cause R to exit immediately (and kill the child processes).

If in any way in R 3.0.3, processes ran during package installation could
outlive R, this is something that shouldn't happen anymore - now R (already
several versions) tries to ensure such processes are terminated.

text:
*[Bug 16723] sink() text goes missing after mclapply*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16723>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |INVALID
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
The short story is that one cannot use sink() with multiple processes, or at
least not in a way that would be reliable. One can still do slightly better
than shown in the example to get better output from the sink() - even, that, it
won't be reliable, anyway. A reliable solution could be based on using a
different sink in each process (parent, and each child), possibly with
time-stamps if some ordering is needed.

Now the long story.

One of the reasons for the surprising results in the example is that sink()
uses an R connection for the output, but the R connection interface has not
been designed to be fork-safe, using the same connection from the child process
and the parent process creates problems.

One of these problems is confusion what is the current file position. the
example uses mode "w+" for the sink, to read the results at the end, so the
sink connection supports both reading and writing. The OS has a single position
in the file advanced both on reading and writing. R on top of this implements
two positions, one for reading and another for writing. It remembers both
positions and it remembers what was the last operation (whether read or write),
so that it can change the OS position accordingly.

So, what happens (I believe, I didn't debug every step, but have read the code
and experimented). When the parent forks, the connection is in the default
"last was read" mode. The first child will want to write to the sink, but the
last operation was read, so it will seek to the current write position (no
effect, it is the beginning), and write the four characters ("ABCD"). The
second executing child will see the last operation was read (which it was in
the parent, so after for in the child), it will hence advance to the current
write position, so again to the beginning (as after fork it sees 0 as that
position), so it will write "ABCD" over the already present "ABCD" in the
output, advancing the OS file position.

Then, the parent will want to read from the sink file. It will know the last
operation was read (it has its own copy of the R connection meta data). It
wants to read, so it doesn't have to seek, so it will use the current OS file
position, which is however at offset 4. So it will miss the first four bytes.

How can one do better?

For instance, do

cat("parent starting children:")

just before calling mclapply(). It will switch the parent R connection to
write. Consequently, one would get output from both children to the sink (the
children will use the OS file position, because they are writing and the
connection was "last written"). Also, the parent will then, when reading see
also its full output (and the children output), because it will switch to
reading from writing, so seek to the beginning.

Using a named sink file opened for appending ("a") should work as well and
probably be more natural, but that one would have to be named and then
re-opened (e.g. "r") for reading.

*[Bug 17193] Console is cleared when using progress bar*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17193>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |INVALID
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
This is a consequence of how RGui was designed - it is normal behavior. The
txtProgressBar(style=3) produces a lot of output, many characters - rewriting
each line very many times (using \r, as mentioned in the documentation). RGui
buffers these characters: how far back it can scroll is controlled by a number
of character (and lines). So, simply, the character limit/buffer fills up.

What one can do to avoid running into this limit: use a different progress bar
(graphical, or textual with style=1) or increase the character buffer size. The
latter can be done from the menu, Edit/GUI preferences/buffer chars, or
directly in the Rconsole file ("bufbytes").

Missing entry in license.db and conversion function spdx2r()

Patch with two changes:

1. Add "File:" entry in license.db for BSD_3_claude.

2. Add a function called spdx2r() to tools/R/license.R. Convert from SPDX
format to the R license info identifier. Tries to match the SPDX Identifier to
"File:" entry (first) or the "SPDX:" entry (second). Supports compound licenses
with "OR". Converts "-or-later" to ">=" notation. Handles different trailing
zero formats in license.db.

Note: This function was written in the context of R Dev Day 2025-08-11, with
contributions from E David Aja and Luis Verde Arregoitia.

Discussed here:

<https://github.com/r-devel/r-dev-day/issues/100>

*[Bug 18186] Any broken symlinks prevent R CMD build from running, even if .Rbuildignored.*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18186>

Jennifer Bryan (<mailto:jenny.f.bryan@gmail.com|jenny.f.bryan@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |jenny.f.bryan@gmail.com

--- Comment #7 from Jennifer Bryan (<mailto:jenny.f.bryan@gmail.com|jenny.f.bryan@gmail.com>) ---
Greetings from R Dev Day @ useR 2025!

I built R-devel from 2025-08-11 r88568 on macOS and applied the patch from
above (a.k.a. attachment 3476).

With patched R-devel, I can `R CMD build` the dummy package from the original
2021-09-05 post that started Bug 18186. And `R CMD build` definitely fails on
this example with unpatched R-devel or R-release. So this is positive evidence
of a fix.

With patched R-devel, I can `R CMD build` the Matrix package obtained via `svn
checkout --quiet <svn://svn.r-forge.r-project.org/svnroot/matrix/pkg/Matrix>`. To
be clear, I can *also* build Matrix without problem with unpatched R-devel,
since the current source on R Forge doesn't have, e.g., any broken symlinks.
But an earlier patch in the Bug 18186 fell over on Matrix, so this seemed worth
checking.

With patched R-devel, I cannot `R CMD build` the symlinkPkg package shared in
the Bug 18186 as [attachment
3449](<https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3449&action=edit>). However I
think that is the expected result. (Sorry this file tree looks so bad here.)

```
~/rrr/rbuildignore/symlinkPkg % tree
.
├── broken_symlink -> does_not_exist
├── DESCRIPTION
├── misc -> /tmp/not_there
├── NAMESPACE
└── R
    └── misc.R -> ../../not_there.R
```

This package has 3 broken symlinks (`broken_symlink`, `misc`, and `R/misc.R`).
The `.Rbuildignore` looks like:

```
^broken_symlink$
^misc
```

which does not actually Rbuildignore the broken `R/misc.R` symlink. If add a
pattern to `.Rbuildignore` that matches `R/misc.R`, then I can build the
package with patched R-devel.

In terms of speed up, I used the patched R-devel to `R CMD build` two packages
I maintain that have large local `revdep/` folders. Here are some observations
from `R CMD build --no-build-vignettes`:

* readxl: `revdep/` is >800MB. Patch makes `R CMD build` 5-6x faster (2.3s vs.
13.5s). 
* usethis: `revdep/` is ~120MB. Patch makes `R CMD build` ~4x faster (2s vs.
8.4s).

The speedup is more modest (1.5x or 2x) for readxl for plain old `R CMD build`,
because a lot of time is spent compiling the package in order to build
vignettes. The speedup stays the same for usethis, which has no compiled code
and only 1 vignette.

Overall the patch seems to be working and it would be great to enforce
`.Rbuildignore` *before* copying package source.

If this patch is accepted, it should presumably close this bug as well as Bug
17549 - When building a package, use inRbuildignore() before copying package
contents to Tdir.

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18928>

            Bug ID: 18928
           Summary: Missing pieces in the C API for environments
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.5.x
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Language
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:lionel.hry@gmail.com|lionel.hry@gmail.com>

The public C API of R is currently missing a few functions related to
environments and bindings that the rlang package (used by the tidyverse) needs
to become conformant.

The following document is a summary of a meeting between Luke Tierney and
tidyverse maintainers (Davis Vaughan, Lionel Henry, and Hadley Wickham) at
useR! 2024: <https://gist.github.com/lionel-/1ebcbd5ec69c0775d514c329522408a3>

The suggested API for environments allows writing an environment cloner in a
package that faithfully reproduce environments without any side effect,
duplicating promises, active bindings, missing values, etc.

`do_rep` code. We have submitted a new patch, which disambiguates between cases
where `each == 1` and `length(times) != length(x)` and the case where `each >
1` and `length(times) != length(x) * each` and only provides an updated error
message in the latter case.

We have also included an update to the documentation in the same patch (also
fixing a typo there).

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18929>

           Summary: Support conciser package version requirement in
                    `requireNamespace()`

          Priority: P5

Created attachment 3519

Allow `package`arg to support optional version requirement comment

Now that bug #18255 has been fixed it would be "nice" for package examples if
we could check if a suggested package of a minimum version number is available
in around 70 characters (so after putting it in an indented if block the total
line doesn't go longer than 80 characters).

`requireNamespace()`'s current `versionCheck` is pretty "verbose" i.e.
something like

```
    if (requireNamespace("rayrender", versionCheck = list(op = ">=", version =
"0.34.3"), quietly = TRUE)) {
```

goes all the way to character 108.

One possible way to make this more concise would be to allow optional version
requirement comments in the `package` argument e.g. `"rayrender (>= 0.34.3)"`:

```
    if (requireNamespace("rayrender (>= 0.34.3)", quietly = TRUE)) {
```

which goes to character 68 and would fit on one line in most style guides.

I've attached a patch with tests and documentation update which should support
this for both `requireNamespace()` and `loadNamespace()` wrapping the
`tools:::.split_op_version()` function that parses `DESCRIPTION` dependencies. 
The main new logic is as follows:

```
    package <- as.character(package)[[1L]]
    if (endsWith(package, ")")) {
        stopifnot(is.null(versionCheck))
        versionCheck <- tools:::.split_op_version(package)
        package <- versionCheck[["name"]]
    }
```

This patch adds `versionCheck` as a named argument of `requireNamespace()`
after the `...` which is technically a breaking change since you can no longer
specify the `versionCheck` as the **fifth** positional argument of
`requireNamespace()`.  If desired I could revise the patch to be fully
backwards compatible by explicitly adding the second through fourth positional
arguments of `loadNamespace()` to `requireNamespace()` and explicitly putting
`versionCheck` as the fifth positional argument of `requireNamespace()`.
